p: While many of the zoonotic microbial agents (e.g. the bacteria causing tuberculosis or diphtheria) are resident in domestic mammals and birds, farmers, breeders and all those involved in food animal production are at risk, since the growing contact between humans and wildlife clearly increases the zoonotic risk (e.g. the example of Ebola fever) (Daszak etÂ al. 2000) . This can be caused either by encroachment of human activity into wilderness areas or by movement of wild animals into areas of human activity (Artsob 2004).
